indicators.justification:
Three mutually reinforcing laws currently govern Malawi's landscape - The Land Act (2016); The Customary Land Act (2016); The Registered Land Amendment Act (2016). (1) It is worth emphasising that these were passed a decade after they were first drafted simply because there was resistance from the elites who have benefited from past legislation (2). These include senior chiefs who were afraid of losing their authority over land (3)

There is no comprehensive and functional electronic database for land tenure data in Malawi. There are paper-based records recording land registration (3). But since The Registered Land Amendment Act (2016) provides for title registration throughout the country for all land categories, including customary estates (4), the potential for having a comprehensive electronic database is there as this as it requires registration of all land as the basis for the determination of ownership. Even so, the same lack of state capacity that is preventing this Act from being fully implemented will possibly prevent the realisation of the database. 

Sources:

(1) de Satgé, Malawi - Context and Land Governance, Land Portal, https://www.landportal.org/book/narratives/2021/malawi#ref53
(2) Ibid
(3) Chinsinga, Blessings. 2008. Exploring the politics of land reforms in Malawi: A case study of the Community Based Rural Land Development Programme (CBRLDP). Research Consortium Programme for Improving Institutions for Pro-Poor Growth.
(4) Ibid

indicators.justification:
Budget and spending information is generally available. The information is partially available on line and off line( visiting a government office). Part of the budget and spending information can be found on the Ministry of Finance website. The chalenge is that the information available on the line may not be comprehensive enough and is not updated regularly. Since there is no legal instrument that requires the Treasury to publish the information. The data available on the website is usually unaudited information, since only after the Auditor General has certified the information or transactions,then the information can be considered official. This aspect of the process is not done to update the records in case, the Auditor General has made some corrections.

Any relevant data can be obtained by invoking the Access to Information Act. The catch word is that "relevant data", as the right to access information is not absolute, there are some conditions which should be fulfilled first before the data could be released.

All in all, the budget and spending information is available, but not publically available on line in a comprehensive manner and up todate. No law or regulations compels the authorities to update or publish information to the general public.

indicators.justification:
All the laws assessed  are silent on minimum standards for metadata  when government data is catalogued and they do not give any provisions regarding technical standards, the standardized process,  quality processes for data processes and documented processed for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users. 
Additionally, whilst  Malawi Regulatory Authority is mandated to monitor  implementation the Cyber Security there is no institution mandated to monitor the compliance of the said Act which can   give room to  problems of financial crimes occuring. 
In view of these gaps  in the above laws, there is need for a data protection law  that can incorporate these standards and processes as a lot of data is being collected by  both government and private institutions and   there is not enough law safeguarding the management of this data.

Further, one  of the articles assessed has pointed out that there is no readily available data on how much information these institution are collecting and how well they are  complying with  the existing laws on the collection and processing of data. This said lack of data is worrisome because without the same, the information  collected could easily be exploited, thus  infringing people's right to  privacy and  inter alia destroying people's confidence  and trust in the public system..

The other concern  mentioned in another one of the articles is that  that there is no data protection regulator and they are no restrictions in Malawi for cross border transfer. All these challenges in the existing laws could make the public who have submitted their data  be susceptible to people misusing the said information.

Further, at the moment there are no laws pertaining to artificial intelligence in the use of data.

For instance  section 71 of the ETCS act states that data can be  still processed without the consent of the data subject as long as it is in the interests of data subject or the  public. indicators.justification:
In Malawi there are a few  laws that speak to data protection briefly. These laws neither  cover data protection matters   exclusively nor in sufficient detail. The laws touch on consent when  it comes to processing of  personal  data and provide redresses against public institutions that   breach data protection laws. However the laws do not specifically give any provisions addressing algorithmic decision making or cover the protection of location related data.
These absence of such provisions in the current framework indicate that   there is a need for a robust stand alone act solely for data protection especially considering that a lot of personal date is now being collected by a number of public  and private bodies without the necessary safeguards.

There is a  draft   data protection Bill which , once enacted, will empower section 21 of the Malawian constitution which has remained largely inoperative due to the lack of a specific law that details its framework for enforcement. In turn, this will help the government to fulfil its obligation on the protection of rights to privacy (3). However, certain limitations have been pointed out. While Clause 5 exempts processing of personal data, if done by individuals "solely for personal, recreational or household purposes from the application of the law," (4) it does not define the terms "personal," "recreational" or "household" purposes - this leaves room for abuse of privacy of the data subject. And Clause 14 provides for a penalty in case of breach of confidentiality of a fine of K5,000,000 (USD 6,289) and imprisonment for five years  - an express double punishment that may lead to miscarriage of justice (5).

indicators.justification:
In Malawi Political financing is totally unregulated. the Political Parties Act of 2018, Presidential and Parliamentary Elections Act and the Constitution of Malawi provides for the provision of both State Political Public financing (which includes funding by the state to all political parties that have attained a prescribed threshold) this is unsustainable as the number of 10% in an election does not relate to the number of seats in parliament,  and Private political Financing ( which includes Private donations, party business, membership fees and other private entities). The Challenge in Malawi is that there is no limit in terms of campaign spending, political parties can spend as they wish. During the 2019 Presidential and Parliamentary Elections evidence was all over as it was difficult to differentiate between a State Function and a Political Campaign Rally. A critical element of the campaign was the incumbent political party widespread and open distribution of cash and items. The presidential and Parliamentary Elections Act on the other hand under section 56 on campaign financing it is also silent in terms of open and transparent financing. As such the sour or manner in which political finances are sources remains a myth. The Polititical Parties Act of 2018 on the other hand accepts the various donations from private entities, thus by considering that:
Donations with a monetary value of at least K1000 000 (US$1 400, 19 February 2019) from an individual donor and at least K2000 000 (US$2 800, 19 February 2019) from an organization must be declared to the Registrar within thirty days of receipt (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (2)(a)).
Furthermore, aggregate donations donated within a month with a monetary value of at least K1000 000 from an individual and at least K2000 000 from an organisation need to be declared (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (2)(b)).
Additionally, persons and organisations who have donated to political parties have to declare to the registrar in cases where the donations exceed K1000 000 for individuals and K2000 000 for organisations (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (4)).

Only the President, Secretary-General or Treasurer-General may formally declare to party funding to the Registrar. Failure by donors or political parties to declare their assets will lead to the those being liable for a fine equal "to the amount of the funds or the value of the assets not declared or in relation to which false information was given, and to imprisonment for two years" (Political Parties Act of 2018, 27 (6)(a) and (b).
